editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for A. Crook at the Green Dragon in Saint Pauls Church-yard, and for H. Brome at the Gunn in Ivy-Lane,

notesStmt.note: 'The English moor' (E.1782[1]) and 'The love-sick court'(E.1782[2]) have separate title pages, continuous pagination and register, and a final leaf of epilogue. 'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

Annotations on Thomason copies: (E.1782[1]; general titlepage): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8"; (E. 1782[3]: "Jan: January"; (E. 1782[5]): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8".
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library.

div.p: The lovesick court or the ambitious Politic.

quote.p:
Nil mea, ceu mos est, commends carmina curo
se nisi comendent carmina dispereant.

div.p: London, printed by J. T. for A. C. and are to be sold by Henry Broom, at the gun in Ivy-lane, 1658.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: A little wit, less learning, no poetry
This playmaker dares boast: 'tis his modesty.
For though his labours have not found least grace,
It puffs not him up or in mind or face,
Which makes him rather in the art disclaim
Bold licence, than to arrogate a name;
Yet to the wit, the scholar, and the poet,
Such as the play is, we must dare to show it
Our judgements to but too: and without fear
Of giving least offence to any ear.
If you find pleasure in't, we boasting none,
Nor you nor we lose by 'Expectation.
Sometimes at poor men's boards the curious find
'Mongst homely fare, some unexpected dish,
Which at great tables they may want and wish:
If in this slight collation you will bind
Us to believe you 'Have pleased your palates here,
Pray bring your friends wi'you next, you know your cheer.

list.item: Philargus, the prince, supposed son of the late slain general.
Philocles, a young nobleman son of the late general, and twin with Philargus.
Euphalus, a gentleman belonging to the King.
Geron, a curious coxcomb and a scholar.
Matho, a villain, servant to Stratocles.
Tersulus, a tailor, servant to Philargus.
Varillus, a barber, servant to Philocles.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Good morrow my good lord. How fares the King?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: More sick in mind then body, by th'opinion,
(Not only of the skilful doctors, but) of all
That come about him.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I that have not seen him
Since he was sick, can guess, then at the cause
Of his distemper. He is sick o'th' subject;
Th'unquiet commons fill his head and breast
With their impertinent discontents and strife.
The peace that his good care has kept 'em in
For many years, still feeding them with plenty,
Hath, like o'er pampered steeds that throw their masters,
Set them at war with him. O misery of Kings!
His virtue breeds their vices; and his goodness
Pulls all their ills upon him. He has been
too long too lenitive: a thousand heads
(Or say a hundred, or but ten) cut off
Of the most gross ones, the prime, leading heads
Of theirs a month since, had preserved him better
Than all his doctors pills can purge him now.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: You are too sharp Disanius. There's a means,
As mild as other of the Kings clear acts,
In agitation now, shall reconcile
All to a common peace no doubt.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What's that Justinius?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Stay: here comes Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I fear, in that
Ambitious pate lies the combustible stuff
Of all this late commotion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why is man
Prescribed on earth to imitate the gods,
But to come nearest them in power and action?
That is to be a King! That only thought
Fills this capacious breast. A King or nothing!

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: He's deep in meditation.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: On no good.
It is some devilish waking dream affects him.
I'll put him out — and as I was about
To say my lord.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What? when Disanius?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: About a month since,
It stick still in my jaws. Be not ambitious,
Affect not popularity. 'tis the most
Notable break-neck in a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: In whom?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I know to whom I speak; would Stratocles
As well known who he is, and what he does:
It would be better for him. Thank me not,
I wish it for the King and kingdoms good,
Not yours I do assure you, my great lord;
Yet mine own peer, if you forget me not.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You take your time sir to make me your mirth.
A time may come —

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: When you may be my King,
And then up goes Disanius. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes, up to court, to be King Stratocles' fool.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: The court now privileges thee, or I would change
A cuff with your great soldiership and popular greatness
With clowns and citizens, and gentry, sprung
By their late peaceful wealth, out of their dongue.
But let 'em thank our pious King, not you
That claim (As merit for your service done)
Their loves and voices.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Cease my lords this strife.
The King may hear on't, whose perplexities
Already are too grievous. Pray be silent,
The King approaches.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: We'll attend his entrance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.stage: Upon those terms they are come then, Eupathus?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Four of the chief in the commotion,
Upon the engagement of my faith, that you
Had passed your kingly word for their return
In safety, I have brought to court, who wait
Your present will and pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bring 'em in.
Disanius, welcome. I thought well to send for you
To take a councillor's part of my late cares
Into your consideration.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I attend
Your highness' pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nearer good Disanius.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do you deal in secret King? The commons sent for
To their examination, and this old
Antagonist of mine called to confront me,
And I prepared by no intelligence
To fit me for th'encounter? Let 'em come.
I must not be denied to stand as fair
in competition for the crown as any man
The King himself elects for his successor;
The people are mine own through all his parts:
He may command their knees, but I their hearts.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stratocles, Justinius, Disanius sit.
My lords, although our laws of Thessaly
To you, as well as to ourselves, are known,
And all our customs, yet for orde's sake
I shall lay open one to you. That is, when
A King deceaseth without issue male
(As I unfortunately must) the commons
Are to elect their King, provided that
He be of noble blood, a soldier, and one
That has done public service for the crown —

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That makes for me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Or else the son of some
Great general slain in battle for his country
(As my Adrastus was.)

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O my brave brother!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Twenty years sorrow for that soldier's loss
Has not worn out his memory.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your grace
Forgets not then soldiers of fresher fame.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Some other time to boast good Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: 'Twere good you'd hear the King — a general,
Or a general's son may be elected. There
Your majesty left.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Or if the sonless King
Yet has a daughter, and he match her in
His life time to a husband that is noble,
He stands immediate heir unto the crown
Against all contradiction.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Now think upon my service, royal sir.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Now think upon my nephews, royal master,
The sons of brave Adrastus, who was slain
Twenty years since in fighting of your battle.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: 'Twere good you would hear the King. The husband of
Your daughter must be elected. There you left, sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It rests now that a speedy choice be made
Of a fit husband, one that may acquire
Eudyna's love, and people's approbation,
The people, (For whose noise I must not rest
Till my successor be appointed to them)
Are wild till this election be made:
They have, in arms, made their demand, and wait
My present answer.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O here they come. These be the principals 4 rustiks.
The heads, the heads, forsooth they call themselves.
Head-carpenter, head-smith, head-plowman, and head-shepherd.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay, pray approach; and seem no more abashed
Here then amongst your giddy-headed routs,
Where every man's a King, and wage your powers
'Gainst mine in soul defiance. Freely speak
Your grievance, and your full demand.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: 'Tis humbly all expressed in this petition.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.p: By all means have a care that, to any question, we give the King good words to his face; he is another manner of man here then we took him for at home.

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.p: I sweat for't. I am sure I have scarce a dry thread in my leather linings.

sp.speaker: 4. Rus tic
sp.p: They made us heads i' the country: but if our headships now, with all our country care should be hanged up at court for displeasing of this good King, for the next Kings good our necks will not be set right a-again in the next King's reign I take it.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: My head itches to be at home again.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: My head itches to be at home again.

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.l: My head and heart both aches for fear. Would
I were honestly hanged out o'the way to be rid on't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: There you may read my lords what we before
Found would be their demand. 'tis for a King
That must succeed me.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: And because you have
Governed them long in peace, by which they thrive
Their wisdom would have you entail that piece
On them for after times; and so they nominate
Ambitious Stratocles to be your heir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Envious Disanius, my merit is
Their motive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cease your strife. — you have stood, more inclined
To lay your choice on Philocles, or Philargus
The twin-born sons of long since slain Adrastus.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: May't please your majesty we are informed
That in their travails unto Delphos, both
Of them are dead.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: That information
Was merely by suggestion (I dare speak it)
Insinuated by Stratocles. They both live
And are upon return.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Would we knew that.
Lord Stratocles then should pardon us. He's a man
Gracious amongst us. But —

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: Philargus! O —
Philargus, be he living.

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.l: I say Philocles.
Brave Philocles is the man.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: False, empty weathercocks.

sp.speaker: 4. Rus tic
sp.l: I say lord Stratocles is the man we know
And ought to honour.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: There lives yet some hope.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: What strange confusions this? Or whither will
You run by several ways? Philargus one,
Another Philocles; a third cries Stratocles.
In this you say you'll have no King at all.
This must be reconciled, or you pull ruin
Upon yourselves. He, whom the King is pleased
To give his daughter to must be your King.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: All that we crave (And that upon our knees)
is, that the King will graciously be pleased
To make a speedy choice, and give us leave
With pardon to depart, and signify
His royal pleasure to the doubtful countries'.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell 'em they shall expect, then, but a month,
In which short time my daughter's marriage
Shall be consummate.

sp.speaker: All rus tic
sp.l: The gods protect your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now, my lords, the commons being at peace,
Let me prevail your private jars to cease.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Madam, the cause is mine; 'tis mine to mourn
In chief, if they be dead. They were your sons,
'Tis true, and though they were your only comforts
Upon this earth, you but resign to heaven
The blessings that it lent you. But to me
They were a pair of equal lovers; and
By me so equally beloved; and by
The King my father so above all men respected
That I by either had been made a Queen,
Which title I for ever will disclaim
If they be dead.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O my Philargus. O my Philocles!
Ye gods I know they did not seek your counsels
Nor dare to approach your altars, but with all
Due reverence and required ceremony.
And could your Delphian oracle, when they
Were friendly competitioners for love,
Answer them but with death?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: The rumor, madam,
Carries so little show of truth, that you
Do ill to take so deep a sense of it;
much worse t'expostulate, as if you had
An injury done you by the gods. Have you
Been from mine infancy my governess,
And careful councel-giver; and must I
Find cause to chide you now? come dry these tears.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Where's my sweet Princess?
Where's my lady governess?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O Garrula, welcome. I could never wish
Thy company more usefully: for thou bringest
Some recreation on thy countenance always.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I am glad my countenance pleases you. It may:
For I have on it now (Could you discern 'em)
A thousand joys dancing within these wrinkles
More than my feeble failing tongue can utter.
And that's a grief to me among all my joys;
The failing of the tongue, the tongue, the tongue
Is a great grief to any woman. But
To one in years, and well in years, as I am,
It is a grief indeed, more than the loss
Of any other member.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: But I pray thee
Let not that grief deprive us of the hearing
Of, at least, one of thy whole thousand joys.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis a report of joy and wonder, Princess;
Enough to make not only you, and you,
But King and kingdom glad, could I but utter't.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thou dost speak well enough, and enough too,
I pray thee tell it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: 'Tis some feigned stuff
She hopes to palliate our sorrows with.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis a report, worth more than all the storeys
That I myself have told in childbed chambers,
To restore spirit to the pallid flesh.
And I have been a woman as good at it
(Without vain boast be't spoke) as any she
In Thessaly, that ere durst undertake
the office of a midwife: and that the Queen
Your mother knew, when I delivered her
Of the sweet babe (Your self.) She is in bliss
Now in Elysium. But you, madam governess,
Can yet remember good old Garrula,
That took into the light your twin-born sons,
And thereby hangs a tale —

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What means this woman?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good Garrula, thy news? thy present story?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis such a story, that could I but utter't
With volubility of tongue! — but oh
This tongue, that fails me now; for all the helps
Of syrups, and sweet sippings. I still go
sp.stage: She sips oft of a bottle ather girdle.
sp.l: Provided, as you see, to cherish it.
And yet it falters with me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: We shall have't
Anon I hope. Placilla, what's your news?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent madam. And I was ambitious
To bring you the first taste of it. But if
Garrula has in that prevented me,
I can with no less joy relate it yet.
My brothers are returned, and safe, from Delphos.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Be thou as true as th'oracle.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Now, madam.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Mother, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: 'Tis that I would ha' told you
Had not my tongue failed me i'th' utterance.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thy tongue ran fast enough, but lost its way.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Three minutes, madam, brings 'em to your presence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: How is it with you, madam? Let not joy
Beget a worse effect than did your fears.
Help, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Ods pity, what d'ye mean.
Madam, look up, and speak up too you were best,
Do you know who talks to you? Speak; and speak well too.
I shall speak that will be worse for you else.
Madam, you know, that I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I am well I thank you, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: O are you so?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I have observed that often in her language,
This chattering midwife glanceth at the knowledge
Of some strange hidden thing, which like as with
A charm, she keeps my governess in awe with.
I guess it but some trifle: for I know
The lady is right virtuous; yet it may
Be worth my inquisition at fit time.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You have felt the comforts of my friendship Garrula,
And had you common charity, you'd forbear me.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I — done madam. Be secure. But yet,
Though I forbear to speak, I not forget.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You have not yet, Placilla, told the means
sp.stage: A shout and crying Philar. And Philocles, etc.
sp.l: Of your rich knowledge.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Nor shall I need now madam
These shouts of joy that followed them to court
Attend them to your presence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O let us meet 'em. Madam, come away.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O ye gods, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I have a son there too, as dear to me
As any mother's only born can be,
Whose name's not voiced with theirs. Yet by your favour
Great madam governess, he has discharged
The office of a governor o'er your sons,
As well as you have over the King's daughter.
And they have sucked more of his Helicon
Then she has of your doctrine: which their breeding
Together with their travels through his care
Will testify (I doubt not) to my honour,
That have brought forth a son of such performance.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Did not I say, 'twas Stratocles that raised
sp.stage: Ent. Dis. Jus. Phila. Philo. Eud. thy: Pla. Geron.
sp.l: That hideous rumor of their deaths, among
His wild idolators, in hope to gain
Election by their ignorance and rudeness?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: 'Twas well those factious heads were wrought to come
Before the King to find his clemency,
And probably that these were living.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: And how they then shrunk in their necks from Stratocles!
It has so laid the flames of his ambition,
That these may safely now tread out the fire.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: Welcome again my princely nephews, welcome.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thanks, courteous uncle.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You interrupt me, brother.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Good woman, cry thee mercy. Mothers are such things!

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Why, what things are we mothers?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O the old night-piece with her dark lantern by her.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You'll give us leave to take
The comforts due unto us in our age,
For which we suffered sorrow in our youth!
Our children are our children young or old.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: So is my horse my horse.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You have replied,
As whilom did a counsellor at law,
Who said his adverse advocate had pleaded
To as much purpose as a hen i'th' forehead.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Geron. thou'rt welcome. Thou still keepest thy humour,
Thy travels ha' not changed thee. Thou camest home
As wise as thou wentest out.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So whilom said,
A miser, having much increased his store,
He had as much still as he had before.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Enough, I'll give thee over.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O my dear offspring; every sight of you
Is a new recompense, and satisfaction
For all the pain and travel of your birth.
In you your father's memory shall live
Beyond the malice of the grave and death:
And I, when my rejoicing shall be full,
And cannot take addition, freely yielding
My flesh to dust, shall yet be blessed by those
Who shall give testimony to your virtue.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Twere a sufficient spur to noble actions
To be rewarded but with your content,
Which to procure we make our business.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Philocles,
Your brow is clouded. Has the oracle
Adjudged against you. Pray let us partake
The knowledge of the Delphian decree;
And which of you stands highest in the favour
Of wise Apollo, to be husband to
Princess Eudyna here the kingdom's heir.
What speaks the oracle?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Such a verdict, madam,
Requires an o Oedipus to construe it.
I neither know't, nor am solicitous
After the meaning.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Wisely spoken, pupil.
So whilom answered an Egyptian porter
To one demanding what he bore concealed?
'Tis therefore covered that thou shouldst not know ▪
The cases are alike.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Pray let us hear it.
Cannot your tutor Geron play the Hermes
T'interpret it?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I am not enigmatical:
But all for apothegms. Besides, I say
(As whilom Aristippus of a riddle)
It is not safe to lose what being bound
Doth trouble us so much.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Yes by all means: for as one whilom said
The blind are best i'th' dark.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My lord, your trumps
Are ever shot at me. Blind as I am,
I perceive that. And make much of your riddle,
I know both what it can and will come to,
Better without the sight of it, than all
you can, with all your wise constructions.
And so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Not in anger, Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Madam, you know I know. I must take leave
To take a nap ▪

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: And governor Geron, wait upon your mother,
Trust our cares with your charge.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So whilom said
A school boy, when another raised his top,
Let me alone, myself can keep it up.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: And now let me entreat that we may hear
The hidden sentence. Happily so many
May guess at the intent.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: She longs to hear
Which of the two is pricked to be her husband.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here it is. If there be any thing.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Let me be clerk. I hope at least to read it.

quote.l: Contend not for the jewel, which
Ere long shall both of you enrich.
Shall make you what you seem to be.

sp.l: Apollo, thy great wisdom hath quite fooled mine.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: Nothing but contradictions.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: As how, Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: He commands here.
Contend not for the jewel — we agree,
Eudyna is the jewel. — which shall both of you enrich.
How shall she enrich us both? Can she be wife to us both?
Then here he bids
Pursue your fortune. — and we both agree
Eudyna is that fortune too: she's both
The jewel we must not contend for; and
The fortune we must both pursue. Then here
He says 'tis she shall make us what we seem to be.
What do we seem? we are no hypocrites
In flesh or spirit; no fantastic bodies
or shadows of humanity.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: No, Delphos is but a den of jugglers, which profanely
Abuse divinity, and pretend a god
Their patron to authorise their delusions.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Nephews, the gods had need be cautilous
For what they speak if you may be their judges.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What thinks good Justinius?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: My lords, here's two commands;
One, that you not contend to gain the jewel;
The other, that you both pursue your fortune.
Both these commands are thus to be obeyed;
Contend not for her as to violate
Your unexampled friendship, which you are
Renowned for o'er all Greece; and both pursue
Your fortune in her without either's grudge,
At tother's happiness in her choice.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Noble Justinius, thanks.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: This we can do.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: And for the happiness which we both aspire to
We here confirm the friendship long since plighted,
Which never shall be broken by Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Noble Philargus.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: So vows Philocles,
'Tis not the cloudy language of the gods
Shall make our breasts tempestuous or stormy:
But with the same serenity and quiet,
As heretofore our hearts shall mingle still,
And fortify their truce. Let the event
Expound their riddle. If good, it is our merit;
If bad, we know our virtue can correct it.
Mean time Philargus take the word of Philocles,
That though there be no happiness on earth
I can esteem above Philargus' friendship,
But fair Eudyna's love, which only is
The treasure I can covet from Philargus;
And cannot look to live but to enjoy it
rather than justle with his friendship, I
Will die to lose it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Noble Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: You have made my vow, my brother Philocles,
And friend, which is above it. I will seek
And rather die than fail to gain her love:
But that, and the whole kingdom in addition
Must divide our friendship or affection.
As we are twins in birth, we'll be in mind
Unto our latest breath. Let Greece hereafter
Forget to mention the Tyndarides
With their alternate deities, and tell
Of two Thessalian brothers could refuse
A happiness (Which only is not heaven)
In detestation of priority;
Would not be happy, 'cause they might not share
An individual, both time and thing.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Love, and ambition (I have heard men say)
Admit no fellowship; it holds not here.
These will have neither wife nor crown alone.
They each desire my love; but neither can
Enjoy't unless he were the other man.
My love is doubly ta'en, yet must gain neither,
Unless I could enjoy them both together. O, ye gods!
Why made ye them two persons, and assigned
To both but one inseparable mind?
Or, why was I marked out to be that one,
That loves and must embrace, or two, or none;
Oh my perplexity.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Look to the Princess.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Madam. How fares the life of goodness.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She sinks. Dear mother, sister; bring your aids.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: To keep the world alive give your assistance.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Ye gods be now auspicious.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: A love-qualm.
To bed with her and call for Cupid's aid,
he best can cure the wound that he has made.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: My lesbia, my Cinthia, my Licoris
Or (Which is best of names) my lovely Doris — that?. I.
I still am thine and cannot commutate,
I am as certain to thee as thy fate.
'Tis not my study, or my travails can
Make me to thee appear another man:
Thou mayest affirm of me as whilom did
Xantippe of her husband whom she chid,
Grave Socrates regardless of his worth
He still returned the same that he went forth.
Before I visit thee, thus mayest thou hear on
Thine in the tribulation of love — Geron.
Ha, ha, ha. Old whilom Geron,! art thou come again?
Could Delphos not detain, nor the sea swallow thee
But I must be in danger to be punished
With the porcupine bristles? Fate deliver me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Doris, you must be vigilant in attendance,
And see that no man pass this lobby, towards
Her grace's lodging. 'tis your charge: look to't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Mistress you know your mother laid that charge
On me before, and I am ready here
To answer every comer in his kind
Had you forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pardon me, I had;
But my care hurts not. One thing more good Doris.
If my dear brother Philocles come to visit,
Prithee call me. Speak, wilt thou.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: — help your head.
I must not stir from hence, yet I must come
To call you forth. Away, somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I trust unto thee Doris.

lg.l: What a sick court is here? She's love-struck too.
I can with half a sense find her disease;
But cannot guess the object of her love.
She keeps the fire so close up in her bosom,
That she will sooner perish by't, then suffer
A spark of it fly out to make discovery.
The Princess she's lovesick for two; and her
Despair of gaining either's her consumption.
But what think I of their loves, when mine own
Is trouble enough? Now the visitants;
My great lords howdies are upon the entry,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good morrow lady.
May I crave admittance to the lady governess?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, you may crave it sir, but not obtain it:
Her nearness to the Princess at this time
Is by so strict necessity required.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: May I prevail then, to impart the duty
I have in charge, unto the lady's daughter?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That is the mistress whom I wait upon,
Though now at remote distance: she attends
Her mother at this instant, and her mother
The Princess in much privacy. If I
May be thought worthy to receive the knowledge
Of what you have in trust unto the Princess,
It shall be orderly conveyed unto her grace.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Lord Stratocles, solicitous for glad tidings,
(Beseeching that her grace be pleased to take
The tender of his service; and affirming
Upon his honour that no rest affects him
Until he shall receive a perfect knowledge
Of her recovery) prays to be advertised
In what condition of health she fares;
or to gain leave to visit her himself.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, you have lost much time: you might have said
How does the Princess? And I answer thus,
She is most dangerously sick; not to be seen
By him or any man.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yet let her know
My lords obsequious care for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'll tell my mistress, who shall certify
Unto my lady, who shall intimate
Unto the Princess what you have left in trust
With me, her grace's handmaid thrice removed.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I will acquaint my lord; who for your care
Shall upon his advancement to the crown
Give me command, who will give present order
Unto my man for your promotion.
Your diligence deserves it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My great lords especially parasite. I am beholden to you.
Here comes another; an importunate,
Though impertinent suitor of mine own.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My beauteous Doris, first my love presented
Unto yourself, my lord Philargus craves
To know how fares the Princess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This comes nearer
To my regard then tother; and deserves
A comfortabler answer. She's not well sir,
But much amended in her health. 'tis like,
Your lord (Would he approach to visit her)
Shall find a fair admission to her grace.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I dare not (To delay my lord a minute
Of these glad tidings.) Stay to prosecute
My love-suit to yourself.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, no; away.
Away good Tersulus; and hazard not
Your lords, for your own fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Yet my Doris —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yet again man.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Be pleased to think of me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I shall, and better of you when you are gone.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Winged with that hope, I fly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A pretty nimble fellow and a tailor.
I could almost affect him, did not this
More supple handed barber put him by.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Sweet Doris! thus, by me lord Philocles
Salutes the Princess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This requires an answer
Of health indeed.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: How fares her highness?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Well. Exceeding well, and longs to see your lord.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'll haste to tell him so

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, good Varillus,
I have not gained a conference with you
Since your return from Delphos.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: At more leisure
I'll tell thee wonders, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Something now.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Ha'you seen your lover Geron, the old tutor,
Since our arrival?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Here is an epistle
Came from him to my hands this morning. Hang him.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Well: he has been the whole mirth of our journey
In the discovery of his love to you.
His meat, his drink, his talk, his sleep, has all
Been Doris, Doris, nothing but your remembrance
Has been the trouble of his company;
I'll tell thee at large hereafter. The fair Princess
Is well you say.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: She was well when I left her,
But subject to much passion: she is well
And ill, and well again all in three minutes.
Great ladies may be so. But if I should
Be sick and well, and sick again and well
Again as oft as she; the world would say
I had it — and had been a courtier, to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: They would say the handmaid had been handled so.
Would they?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Like enough, but great ones must not be talked on

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You have detained me to my undoing.
See, my lord!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'll send his sister to appease him.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: You have done ill Varillus to neglect
A duty of that consequence, that I
Expected in your quick return, was this
A time to loiter?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: My good lord, the Princess
Is well again; restored to absolute health.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: 'Tis happy news. But why was I delayed
In this account? was it too precious for me?
Redeem your fault by some ensuing service,
Or you may lose a master, that has loved you.
I must proceed to gain Eudina's love
From my Philargus or l lose myself.
And gaining it, I must forgo Philargus,
And equally be lost. O sister, welcome.
I must request your aid.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: In any thing
Wherein I may be useful, best of brothers.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I would entreat you be my advocate
In love unto Eudina. — oh, but hold,
Shall I be treacherous unto my brother?
A brother! What's a brother? A mere name;
A title which we give to those that lodged
In the same womb; so bedfellows are brothers;
So men, inhabiting one town, or country
Are brothers too: for though the place containing
Be greater, the relation is the same.
A friend! I that's the thing I violate,
Than which, nor earth nor heaven hath ought more sacred ▪
'Tis my Philargus, nay myself I injure,
if I content myself.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why, brother Philocles —
Did I say brother? How my tongue conspires
To torture me! If brother be a naked
Title or name (As he suggests) I would
It had nor being, name, nor title. Philocles
You're passionate.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Fond reason I disclaim thee,
Love is a strain beyond thee, and approaches
The god's estate: friendship's a moral virtue
Fitter for disputation, than observance.
Eudina. O Eudina! In what price
Art thou with me, for whom I cast away
The souls whole treasury reason and virtue?
Placilla, you must woe Eudina for me.
Do you startle at it? Pray do't, as you love me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If I were she you should not need an advocate.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I charge you by this kiss. —

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your wages
Corrupts your agent to be false. O whither;
Into what sands will the rash pilot, love?
Drive this weak vessel? did I call it love?
'Tis sooty, hellish fire; unlawful flame:
Yet such as we may easier tax, then tame.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: What troubles you Placilla? O you are
Already entertained to mediate
For him you better love, Philargus, do:
He best deserves her; I'll woe for him too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, my lady calls for you? My lord
The Princess has ta'en notice of your visit
And wishes you draw nearer if you please.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I meet that wish with swift, but fearful feet.
My joys are bitter, and my woes are sweet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have heard men say when they on gamesters look
(Though equally affected to both parties,
Or both were strangers to 'em yet) they'll yield
a secret inclination which should win.
I am for Philocles, now, against Philargus,
Who is as noble, and as free to me,
As ever Philocles was. But tarry Doris;
You have a bet upon the game I take it,
Your love unto Varillus. If his lord
Rise to a kingdom, you may hope to climb
The ladder of a ladyship by the man.
But not too fast: here's one pursues the game
That is as like to win. Why if he does?
His follower Tersulus loves me passed Varillus,
And may as much advance me. But I love not
Him, and the love of honour above husbands
Has been so common among ladies, that
The fashions stale and ugly.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: So't must be.
And so by transposition of my love
I shall be quiet, and Philocles doubly happy.
Doris, go seek my mother, and perceive
If I may see the Princess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Love, thou art well compared to fire, which where
It doth obey and serve being commanded
By higher powers of the soul, it fares
Like to the stone or jewel of a ring,
Which joins the orb, and gives it price and luster:
So glorious is that love, so necessary.
But, where it rules and is predominant,
It tyrannizeth; reason is imprisoned;
The will confined; and the memory
(The treasury of notions) clean exhausted;
And all the senses slavishly chained up
To act th'injunctions of insulting love,
Parched on the beauty of a woman. Thou
Masculine love, known by the name of friendship
Art peaceful and morigerous: but that
of woman, is imperious and cruel.
Why should I then lose Philocles for Eudina?
sp.stage: Ent. Eudina. Thymile Eudi. reading a letter.
sp.l: Why? Can I look on her and ask a reason?
O the divinity of woman! sure
There is no heaven without 'em. If the gods
Should thrust out Jove as he deposed his father
And elect me to be their thunderer
I'd not drink nectar to forgo Eudina.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Fie, fie Philargus, you're a sluggish lover.
I have been careful for you, yea and partial
Against your brother Philocles, to prefer
Your love to his: and you to suffer him
A whole hour opportunity before you!

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Has he been here?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And is. Only for you
I have beguiled him of her presence, that
Till you have made first presentation
Of love to her he shall have no access.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Now Philocles, I suffer in thy injury;
And to proceed in it were treachery.
I would retire — but that magnetic beauty
To which are chained thousands of hearts and eyes
Has captived mine: nor must I seem to slight
A mother's care. She's not the first ('tis known)
That of two sons hath best affected one.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Why move you not Philargus towards the Princess.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Madam, you see she's busy.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Stratocles —
May thy ambition hoist thee into air;
And thy loose wings, like thy licentious paper,
There failing thee, let fall thy vicious body
To earth, as here thy name lies to be trod on.
Philargus, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Princely madam,
That language from your gracious lips is powerful
To save him from the grave, that only lives
by your free favours.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Nay, my dear Philargus,
I thought me nearer to you, than that you
Should rove at me with courtship. Stratocles
(The emblem of whose pride lies there in paper)
Shot from afar indeed; yet, like a Jove
(A self-conceited one) presumed to strike
Love by command into me by his letters.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I cannot flatter pride, nor undervalue
Abilities. 'tis true that Stratocles
Has been a useful servant to the state;
But, doubtless, he would make as ill a master.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: No more of him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Nor more be thought of him.
And therefore madam, by your fair command,
To avoid all court-circumlocutions,
I tender thus my service, and crave hearing.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You have it freely.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: To avoid all lets,
I will withdraw myself.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The King has graciously been pleased, in lieu
Of my slain father's services; and for love
To us his sons, (By us much undeserved)
To recommend unto your noble choice
My brother and myself. You standing doubtful
Whether to choose, we to avoid dispute
Of violating friendship, did implore
The council of the oracle to direct
You in th'election. But the hidden sense
In the dark sentence hath perplexed both you
And us with more anxiety.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: It is too true.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Yet you are not prescribed; your choice is free.
To take your lot in Philocles or me.
We both, by strong injunction must pursue
Your sacred love, yet keep our friendship true.
Then thus illustrious madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Not so low.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: As low as future duty must compel me,
When you shall be my Queen, let me beseech
The favour that I seek and would obtain,
Equal with heavenly bliss, to shine on Philocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: That he may be your King?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: May he prove so.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Be all example lost.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Friendship, with favour, may
Hold between King and subject: but one throne
Cannot estate two Kings; Love's number's one.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O my Philargus, you have opened now
The meaning of the oracle. I have the sense
Most perfectly. You have beyond example
Preserved your friendship with your brother; and
In wooing for him have won me to yourself.
I am your own.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I am amid the gods.
The wealth o'th' world, the beauty of the heavens,
And powers of both shall not redeem my interest.
— provided that I lose not Philocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: In that your constancy you win me more.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your importunity hath prevailed. See Philocles,
The Princess, and Philargus.

sp.speaker: Philoe.
sp.l: O, you are partial.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O help, my brother; speak, dear Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Ye gods, how comes this? Let me raise him up,
Brother, and friend; speak, 'tis Philargus calls thee.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Philargus, let me go. 'tis your advantage.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Let me request the cause of your disturbance,
Good Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philo.
sp.l: No other but myself.
Honoured Eudyna: for, who feeds to danger
Upon a dish he loves, ought not to blame
The meat, but his unbridled appetite.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How do you now? What a cold moisture
Spreads o'er his temples here.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Let me come to him:

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I can read his grief.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What's that to the redress?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: The Delphian god, medicines inventor knows
That and not I.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: His grief's a jealous passion
Upon my supposed favour to Philargus.
Shake it off Philocles, I am thine, as much
As ere I was, or his.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: It is no jealousy
Only a fear Philargus had broke friendship:
So, my souls better part exited, left
The other languishing.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Had you expired
In that belief, and I had understood it,
My shadow should have posted after yours
Unto the Elysian fields to vindicate
So causeless imputation.

sp.speaker: Thy:
sp.l: And because
You charged my son with partiality
Let us remove, Philargus, come Placilla.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: You will not take him from me. Stay Philargus.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What would you do with both?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I may not stir,
When she, whose power above me countermands
The precepts of the gods requires my stay.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What not to give you brother Philocles
An opportunity for equal hearing?
Your grace will not deny't him.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: True, I may not.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: That spell convinces all. Friendships above,
And must control obedience, and love.
'Tis not to injure thee my dear Philargus,
That here I linger, to oppose thy love;
but to prefer it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What says Philocles?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: To say I love you, madam, with a zeal
That dares to meet the trial of martyrdom,
And suffer't for your sake, might get a name,
A glorious one, and an immortal crown:
Yet so I should forgo (In leaving you
On earth, a heaven on it) the bliss,
Which, grieving, I should in Elysium miss.
No, I will love you better than to die,
And be mine own chief mourner; yet must crave,
Under your gracious favour, leave to suffer
More than a thousand deaths, that is, to live
And part with my fair hopes in you for ever.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What means my Philocles?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Princely madam,
Consider the necessity, which now
By further search I gather from the hidden
Oraculous perduit; by which I am tied
Not to contend for you, that is, I must not
Wound friendship in Philargus: but pursue
My fortune, which is to gain love from you.
For whom it says not, but the meanings plain,
I for Philargus should your love obtain.
The gods deal after as they please with me,
My suit is that you take Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O —
Philocles you have made a double conquest
For you have got the victory of me
Which was before assigned unto Philargus.
Your fortune thus embraces you

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: This now,
And with Philargus' friendship were to me
A fortune above the envy of the gods.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: He cannot disallow't. He wooed me for you,
And won me to himself, as you have now
Suing for him.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I must not hold you then.
His title, as his friendship precedes mine.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Yet still the choice is mine. I may take you
Without offence to him. But now he comes,
And has again an equal interest,
Strange love! In others absence I took either
And loved each best; now both at once appear,
Neither is mine. Fate, let me die to one
Rather than live in this confusion.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now madam, whethers love do you approve.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Confound me not with question. They are each
Wedded to others friendship: either is
More studious for the other than himself.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: And ever must.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: And will be.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: So will I
For both of you then for myself.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Then let's continue thus with maiden love,
With modest freedom, unsuspected joys,
As we had all been formed in one womb,
Till heaven determine of us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To determine
Of you Eudyna, is by heaven committed
In present unto me. On you depends
The future glory and prosperity,
Both of my house and kingdom. 'tis besides,
Exacted of me by my near allies,
And by my subjects (Whom I must secure)
To constitute a successor: and no longer
Will I expect your answer, than five days.
By then you must declare who is your husband;
Or else expect one from myself; the man
Whose name I am as loath to mention
As you to hear, even Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Nay, death first.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be you obedient; and by the way,
Take my approvement of lord Philocles,
Not that I slight Philargus.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Here's a mystery too,
As dark as that from Delphos. He approves
My choice of Philocles, slighting not Philargus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come both you equal brothers; leave her to
Her thoughts a while.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: In all obedience.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What strange amazement hath surprised you madam?
No study, nor no strife can alter fate
Or the decrees, the gods determinate.
A husband you shall have, be confident.
Be, as you were; secure of the event,
Till time produce it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam, be yourself.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Yet five days for love's war. Jove grant I have
By then, to end the strife, a peaceful grave.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Would you thus offer, by your own disease
To shorten your mother's days? Or can you pine
And I not grieve? or cannot grief kill me
Do you think?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A wise philosopher whilom did affirm,
That women who have passed the fire of love
Have hearts, which grief can neither pierce, ne move.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Son, your philosophy fails you, as your love
Blinds you: for Cupid's fire I know may be
Quenched by old age: but grief's unquenchable.
My tongue still falters with me (There's my grief)
and there are not so many fathoms 'twixt
A woman's tongue and heart, but grief may find
The bottom, but for care to keep it up
By sending down an antidote before it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But whilom did the lovesick poet prove,
No antidote against the power of love.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Forbear your whiloms, and your old said saws,
And since you are in love, and by that love
Grown sick with the concealment.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As whilom
Th' Athenian boy who stole a fox did hide
Under his coat his theft from being descried
Until it tore his genitals — his entrails
I should have said.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: No more I say
Of your disease, but to the cure, which is
The love of Doris. How ha'you tried her, son.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By oratory, epistles, and by gifts
Which whilom Ovid said were best of shifts.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yes, such a gift it might be, and so fastened.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But she, as whilom said anominus
Retorteth all with scorn injurious.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yet will you leave your whiloms? And go seek
My lady governess? say I would speak with her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: But whilom said Diogenes ('tis true)
To one that would, I will not speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Will you say as I say; and do as you're bidden?
It is not her great Ladyship's daughter's handmaid
Shall scorn my son while I know what I know.
If you love Doris, run and tell her so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For Doris love, as whilom Daedalus.
I will take wing. But see I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O Garrula! well found, I was in quest of you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And I was e'en a sending for you, madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What an imperious beldame's this. But I
Must humour her. Sending for me do you say?
For what, good Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Sending for you? Yes madam, so I said,
And say't again. What, what, I know what I know.
You know I do; and that there is no such
Distinction 'twixt the honours of your birth
And place; and mine of age and knowledge, but
You might vouchsafe the summons when I send.

sp.speaker: Thy,
sp.l: What needs this Garrula? I am here you see.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You know I know, and have deserved some favours,
I do not boast for what. You know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O me!
Who trust those secrets whereon honour rests
To custody in mercenary breasts
Do slave nobility; and though they pay
A daily ransom, never redeemed away.
Pray let us be more private, though indeed
I love your son for his great care of mine.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: O, do you so? Go forth son Geron, till
I call. All shall go well I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Whilom, so
Said a physician, meaning to restore,
And killed the patient was but sick before.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Why Garrula do you maintain a strife
Still in my grieved mind 'twixt hope and fear?
Cannot so many years of my known kindness
Win yet a confidence of secrecy.
You are as deeply bound by oath too as myself.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I do confess my oath, and would not break it;
Yet, madam, as you are a woman, you
May know a broken oath is no such burden
As a great secret is; besides the tickling
A woman has to in and out with't. O
The tongue itch is intolerable! And were I
A woman of tongue, as most are of my calling
(Though midwives ha' been held the best at secret
Councel keeping) it had been out I fear.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: But still take heed dear Garrula.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Yes madam.
Yet there are kindnesses required on your part.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Have I not still been kind?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My memory serves me; and but that my tongue
Now falters with me — I could recount
All the rewards I have had from time to time,
Since you translated me from a country housewife,
Into the midwife royal; what in gowns,
In gold, in jewels, chains and rings; and (Which
I prize 'bove all) my syrrops and my sippings.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your place of honour in the court —

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: What, what?
I hope I had that before i'the King's favour,
As his Queen's midwife. She is in Elysium.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Then Garrula your learned son's preferment,
Tutor and governor to my sons.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Thereby
Hangs a tale, madam. Now I come to th'point;
My son affects your daughter's handmaid Doris,
Who slights his love. I must now by your power
Obtain her for my son.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Be confident,
Though I confess I hold her worthless of him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I tell him so: but love has blinded him.
Ho Geron, I say Geron, come and hear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So whilom prisoners have been called to come
From dungeon deep to hear a blacker doom.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Geron, be comforted. By all my power,
Doris shall be your own.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then whilom, as
Ovid his Corynna sweet, said o —
She comes, she comes. My joys do overflow.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now Doris, what portends your haste? Speak maid,
Is it to Geron, or to me, your business?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: His ill looks, had almost made me miscarry't.
Madam, the Princess instantly desires
Your company.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: But by her grace's favour,
And your leave, Doris, I will trench so far
On both your patiences, and for your good,
As to be witness of an interchange
Of some few words twixt Geron and yourself.
Why look you from him so? he loves you, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That's more than I ere knew, or read, by all
He speaks or writes to me. He cloaths his words
In furs and hoods, so, that I cannot find
The naked meaning of his business, madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Speak plainly to her, Geron.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: To her son.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My business is the same, that whilom drew
Demosthenes to Corinth, some repentance,
So I pay not too dear.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lo you there, madam.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You must speak plainer, son.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And be you kinder, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But not so kind, good madam, as to grant
I know not what.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O forfeit not the praise
That whilom Aristotle gave your sex,
To be enriched with piety and pity.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not what to pity, but your want
Of utterance. It is some horrid thing
That you desire, and are ashamed to speak it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No, gentle Doris, nothing but the thing,
Whereby great Alexander whilom said,
He knew himself a mortal, and no god,
Coition —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Be it what it will; I cannot
Give what I understand not. You're too aloof.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: There's comfort, son. And I'll give thee instructions
To come more close to her.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I'll ease your care,
And be myself his agent. He's too learned,
Geron, you speak too learnedly, as if
You wooed a muse: and Doris understands not,
But by your posture, what you'd have. I'll put
Your meaning into woman's words; and such
As shall be sure to speed. But first I'll wait
Upon the Princess. Garrula, will you go?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And thank you for my son: but still — I know.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Nay, I will do't Geron, be confident.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I thank your ladyship as much as they
Who whilom — whilom —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Knew not what to say.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: He's overjoyed.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Go Geron, lead the way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray trouble me no further. I have said,
That if in five days' space she make not choice
Of one of those whom (I must tell you Stratocles)
She loves, and I prefer before you, then
I'll weigh your suit, and reasons; and till then
I say't again, you are a trouble to me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A trouble sir? That were a time that knew me,
A trouble to your enemies, not you,
When this same lump of earth (Which now's a trouble)
Stood a sole bulwark of your realm; repelling
Arms of foes; shrouding your fearful subjects
Under my shield; guarding your fields and vineyards
From desolation; your palaces from ruin;
And am I now a trouble?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Stratocles,
You lose the glory of your deeds by blazing
your own renown. He that commends himself,
Speaks upon trust, and is his hearers slave.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Peace, envy, and be thankful for thy life
Which thy tongue forfeits.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Let my mildness tell you,
You are irreverent before the King,
Who has not been forgetful of your worth,
Nor slow in your reward. Then moderate
Your heat with counsel; and be first assistant
Unto the public good: so shall you merit
The first regard in honours and affairs
Of private nature.

sp.speaker: Sra.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This oracle
Troubles me not a little. I had thought
Thereby to have declined this weighty care
From my declining shoulders, and have given
My country satisfaction, and myself,
In choosing of a son and successor.
But I am prisoner in the labyrinth
Of the god's verdict.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Their sublimity
In matters of the future seldom stoops
To humane apprehension; yet vouchsafes
To answer our demands: but chides withal
Our too much incense with obscurity.
Your grace however may presume, where they
Shall deign to spend a word, and take an offering,
It is a certain augury of good.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast allayed my fear. Justinus come,
Lead me thy brains assistance. For in thee
I find a temper that accords with me.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Soldier, I dare yet tell thee thou art rash;
Foolish as valiant; and as easily mayest
For all thy lostiness be undermined
As the base bramble: boasting weakness, thee
and promising ambition leads thee up
An earthly exhalation into th'air;
Where with a little borrowed light, one moment,
Thou shinest the mark and wonder of all eyes;
But soon consumed and darted to the centre,
Becomest the scorn of men and sport of children.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You are oath sect of cinicks, and have learned
To bark philosophy.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Then shall you hear
Your now adorning multitude upbraid
Your insolence and pride, and gain the name
Of prophets by your downfall, while one swears
He had foretold it long; another dreamt it;
All jointly cry we never could endure him;
See what a look he has; what brawny lips;
What poisonous eyes; and what an impudent front!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You will outrun your privilege of prating
And suffer for't.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I am too prodigal
Of seed upon so flinty soil as thou.
Be as thou art, and perish.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ignorant wretch,
That out of all thy bookish theory
Knows not the soul to be aerial
And of a soaring nature; not unlike
The noble falcon that will never cease
To work above all that tops her. The supreme
Estate on earth, and next unto the gods
Is majesty; and that's my present gain,
Though I have all but that, yet wanting that
All is as none to me: and since my way
Must be upon the ruins (Sour Disanius)
Of thee, and of thy glories in thy nephews
The Kings dear darlings, for whose precious sakes
I must attend five days (Yet be a trouble)
I'll travail through your bloods: thyself has gi'n me
The quicker motion by thy timely envy.
Thou hast set spurs to the pale horse of death,
That into dust shall trample all those lets
Which stand twixt me and the Thessalian crown,
Upon whose back I'll set this rider.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My sovereign lord.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I like that compellation:
Thou stillest me as thou wishest me, on whom
Depends thy consequent advancement, Matho.
But we but dream of sovereignty and sleep
To the achievement: something must be done
With wakeful eyes and ready hands my Matho.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now my King speaks himself. Let but your eye
Find out the way these ready hands shall act
The strength of your designs. I can perceive
That now the labour of your jove-like brain
Is bringing forth the Pallas, shall inspire
Me, to perform the work of my advancement.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet ripe for the delivery,
But thou shalt quickly have it. Follow me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good madam, let me be excused. The mirth
You offered to allay or quench my sorrows
Might have been well received at former times:
But now it is unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet think on't, madam,
How gravely Geron goes, and with what scorn
The wanton girl recoils.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Good, speak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Then beldame Garrula's reasons urging Doris ▪
showing how either of his pupil's grace
In your electing Philocles or Philargus,
Though to them doubtful, is a sure advancement
To her by Geron.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Still you move like those
That do in merry tales misspend their breath
To those that are that day marked out for death.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may not say so (Madam) 'tis in you
By taking one, to give new life to two;
Yourself, and if you'll give me leave to name
The other, be it Philargus: or, if chance
Shall favour better, Philocles or him,
Let it be him that gives you the first visit.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: That were to fancy in ourselves an oracle;
Or to give fortune power, to execute
The judgement of the Delphian god.

sp.speaker: Thy
sp.l: Who knows
But that his oracle would have it so.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Was it for that you now sent for Philargus.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Say, shall it be so madam; or suppose so?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: This pleases better yet than Gerons wooing.
Praythee Placilla sing. And may thy voice
Attract him that may prove the happier choice.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I'll try my best in notes, and what they want
I'll strive to make effectual in my wishes.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Thanks kind Placilla. — but the leaden weights
Of sleep oppress mine eyelids, and I shall not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet sit, and let her sing: you'll sleep the better.
sp.stage: Placilla sings. After a strain or two, Eudina sleeps, and enters, as a vision at the several doors, Philargus and Philocles; they meet and embrace affectionately: then whisper a while: then suddenly start off, and draw their swords: menace each other, and severally depart. The song ended, Eudina affrightedly starts up.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Stay Philocles, stay Philargus. Let not fury
Lead you to end that difference with your swords,
Which only fits my life to satisfy.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: What means your grace.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Pursue 'em, with prevention,
Before they meet again, or one or both
Must perish; did you not observe their challenge,
And either's daring other to the field?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Who madam, where? and when?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Now; here; your sons.
How can you ask?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Because we were awake
And saw nothing.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Collect your spirits madam: you slept.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: It was an ominous dream then.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: And of good,
I dare divine it madam. And now see
Whom fortune first hath sent to be your choice.
Philargus, you have won the glorious prize.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But dos the glory of the world, Eudina, grant it.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: My affrightment shakes me still —
Oh my Philargus, I am now inspired
Sure by a vision from the gods, with knowledge,
That, in my choice of you, or Philocles,
I shall become the ruin of you both.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Tis not in fate to wound our common friendship.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: 'Tis better in myself to kill the danger.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The gods avert such purposes. If you
Deprive the world of your fair self, than we
Both fall by necessary consequence.
But what are we? This Thessaly must suffer.
The King must yield, to see a new and strange
Succession appointed to his crown;
And by his subjects, not himself.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: 'Tis that
deters me: yet let me prevail Philargus
(To quit me of my fears) that ere I pass
My faith unto a husband, your and Philocles,
Before the gods, your mother, and myself,
Once more, do celebrate your vow of friendship.
And let me be excused in this: for I
Must tell you, dear Philargus, that though now
My love be fixed on one of you (Albeit
I name not which) I will not take him with
Least scruple of a fear of losing him
Again by th'other's spite; nor leave that other
Less loved by me, than now he is, for ever;
And though but one can be possessed of me
One friendship, yet, must marry us all three.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: The gods have spoke it in you; it is their
Divine injunction; madam, I obey it,
And dare engage as much for Philocles.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This is most fair: now, till you meet, 'tis fit
You fall on lighter purposes for your health.
Son, here was mirth today; although the Princess
Relished it not.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I heard of Geron's love
To his fair Doris. We are now become
His tutors, madam, to be amorous.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Placilla, come you hither. I observe
A change in you of late; and do suspect
The reason. What! do you blush at my suspicion?
Nay then you make't my knowledge. You are in love.
I'll yet come nearer you. I guess with whom:
And at fit time I'll school you for't.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Come madam;
Now if you please we'll take some air.
Craves leave to seek his brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I wait o'your grace. Nay, do not look displeased:
I tell you girl, there is danger in it.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Stay Placilla.
What! has my mother chid you. I'll not question
Her reason, nor your fault; but pray thee sister
If Philocles approach to see the Princess
Ere my return, tell him I stay at's lodging,
First, to confer with him.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I will my brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Introth thou weepst. Therefore to comfort you,
Because I know by some infallible signs,
You are more tender of his love than mine.
He stands in equal competition yet
With me for fair Eudina. And if fortune
Allots her me, I'll be as kind a brother
And still the same to you as Philocles.
I pray thee dry thine eyes.
sp.stage: Ent. Matho disguised with a letter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If a disguised face and a counterfeit hand
Ever prevailed, may these in this plot speed.
My lord, I had this in charge to render to you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I am discovered in my lawless love.
Remember, Cupid, whom thou makest thy anvil;
A poor weak virgin. If thou art a God,
Be just and reasonable: it savours not
Of justice, to provoke incestuous flames,
Nor reason to enforce an ardency
Of things impossible. Let me not burn
With neighbouring fire, which, to enjoy, I must
Therefore despair because it is so near.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Ha! where's this fellow? is he gone?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yes, brother.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Tis Philocles his hand! An eager challenge!
A challenge, and to me, his friend and brother.
Now oracle, where's your riddle? Answer me,
Apollo's fiddlestick. O ye Delphian priests,
you hang religion up, like painted clothes
Before unseemly walls, to cloak their filth
And palliate their wicked mysteries.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How do you brother?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Sick in Philocles.
You'll hear more of his kindness to you shortly.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He suspects too, with much displeasure, my
Unreasonable love to Philocles.
But why should we be reasons followers
With loss of liberty? which of the creatures
Alleys his heat towards any of his kind,
'Cause the same belly gave them being? They
Observe no difference of sire, or dam,
Brother, or sister, being mature for love.
Ah, whither am I going? Bestial thoughts
Forth of my bosom; leave me not my soul,
Or my soul's better part, my reason. O
It was returning but a flaming shaft
Of love has set it's mansion afire
And frights it back again.

sp.speaker: Philoc. Placilla.
sp.l: Sister.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: That name of sister, like a violent cold
Upon an extreme heat, fevers my blood
To death.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Methinks you are sad and troubled sister.
Why thus alone? Or have you entertained
That troublesome companion, love? Come tell me
I can advise you very learnedly:
For Cupid's scholars are more exquisite
In giving council then in using it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How shall I answer him? I dare not look on.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Why are you sad.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Out of conformity
Unto the present garb: I have assumed
Only a veil of sadness.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Thou art only happy,
Whose sorrow is but outward, as a stranger
Called to be present at a funeral
Clads himself like the rest, is serious,
And silent with a countenance dejected,
And testudineous pace; but has not tears,
No groanings for a loss to him unknown:
The obsequies performed unclothes himself
Of grief and weeds together. But my sister,
You are not pleased to talk upon this subject.
Where is the Princess?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He has given me now a colour for my sadness.
The Princess is retired; she has been troubled
With a most fearful dream of a duello
Betwixt you and Philargus to be fought.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: With friendly courtesies?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Nay, with swords she said.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Philargus hath been with her, and to him
She told her fears, enjoining him, that both
Of you should come, and jointly before her
Declare your constant friendship.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: That's soon done.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But trust me sir, I fear Philargus took not
All as she meant it; for at his departing,
He looked displeasedly; and, when I demanded
His health's condition, he said he was sick
In Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: In Philocles his absence,
As I am in his. That was his meaning sister.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pardon my fear; which is, that he's not friends w'ye.

sp.speaker: Pheloc.
sp.l: Away, your fear has made you idle.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No.
It is my love, in that black horror clad,
Which will, before it leaves me, make me mad.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I'll seek him out.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: My lord, I was commanded
To convey these into your lordship's hands.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: By whom were you employed?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: My lord 'twas not
The man that moved me. For I know him not;
But the reward. I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: My brother write. Ha! are we at such distance?
Thou art no prophetess, Placilla, art thou?
sp.stage: Brother Philocles, we are the laughing stock of the Natition; and injurious both to the King, our country, the divine Eudina, and ourselves, by our childish love. The time is short, meet me, (I conjure you by our friendship) within three hours, in the North vale of Tempe; where it shall be the god's election to take one of us, and leave the other for Eudina. Expostulate not with yourself, much less with me otherwise then by weapon, or never expect to see your brother Philargus.
sp.l: O gods and men! where shall we go to find
Friendship and truth? Be't so: for in th'event
We may be happy both: but with this odds;
One with Eudina, tother with the gods.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: We should love one another, brother Tersulus,
More inwardly, and be in friendship true
As our lords are. Prithee let their example
Piece up all difference betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Piece up,
I know your meaning and your jeer Varillus,
In your piece up.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Fie on thy jealousy. 'cause thou art a tailor,
Howe'er a gentleman by place, thou think'st
I jeer thy quality.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You should not. For
Look back unto the world's beginning; there
You'llfind a tailor was before a barber.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Nay if you go to rip up old antiquity.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Rippe! there he is again.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You may as well
Collect, that the first man (Who you suggest
Was his own tailor) was his own barber first.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Do you think he did not scratch his head
In casting how to fashion out his breeches?
And that's in part, you know, the barber's office.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The scraching of the head.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And still
In use 'mongst tailors on themselves. But note
The foul corruptions brought in by time;
Of old they did but rub invention up,
How to contrive their work: but now their heads
Wrists, fingers, all have got an itch by't, which
Nothing but stealing can allay; though that
Can never cure it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Lying and stealing went
Of old together: now they are shared it seems
Between the barber and the tailor.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Sharp.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Your instruments are sharp as mine, sir barber,
And you can pick more out of your lords ears
Then I take from his garments with my shears.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Agree good brother, or would we had Doris
To stickle twixt us.
There you're afore me too.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: But come, lords followers are their apes in most things,
Why should not we be as friendly rivals, now
In Doris love, as are our lords in the
Princess Eudina's. We will take up a fashion.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Varillus, where's your lord?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I know not Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Tersulus, where's yours?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I know not Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You echo one another. You're commanded
Both by the Princess and the governess
To seek 'em out.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your love commands our stay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Coupled together? Go yet one of you.
You I can spare best.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Why him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You then.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Why him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you conspire? I will return your care.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Nay gentle Doris stay. For, 'tis in vain
To seek our lords. They are both rod singly forth
To take the air. Mine an hour since.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Mine even now. I came but since to call
My brother Tersulus.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your brother Tersulus?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As deeply vowed in friendship as our lords are.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: It is with us as 'tis with them: we both
Are brothers, friends; yet rivals in your love.
Can you now, as the Princess is to them,
Be equally affected to us both?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you stay me to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Nay, dear Doris.
We love our lords? and as you love the Princess,
Who loves them, love you us. You are Eudina,
I Philocles, and he Philargus is.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Are the men mad.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Suppose so gentle Doris.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: The King commands you to make present choice
Of one of us, or else ambitious Stratocles
(That's Geron) must enjoy you. Now sweet Princess
Be speedy in your choice. The kingdoms good
Depends upon it. And in your election,
Oh make Philargus blessed: he best deserves you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Admired friend, and brother Philocles,
Your courtesy o'ercomes me: I must sue,
Though my heart aches the while as much for you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This is fine fooling —
Good barber Philocles, and tailor Philargus,
You shall not need to trim up his affection,
Nor you to stitch up his with your forced courtesies.
I know, in this, each woos but for himself,
And my affection runs as even betwixt you,
As nothing but your sizors, or your shears
Had parted.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: See Stratocles, alias Geron.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So whilom did contend two warlike princes
For a fair hand, till a powerful King
Subdued them both and it. Doris, take heed,
Be wary in your conversation
(As whilom Tully warned his tender son)
With such plebeians, lest their vulgar breeding
Corrupt your education.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Must she be
Your pupil learned Geron.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And myself
Her only study; such as whilom was;
Ulysses to Penelope.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Take heed Doris
How you become his wife: for he will love you
So by the book, as he will never lie with you
without an author for't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, she shall be
More precious to me then Homer's Iliads,
Whilom to Alexander, which he made
His mighty bedfellow: but why stand I
To render this account? The Princess sent you,
Doris, to call their lords to walk with her,
And take the air of Tempe.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: They are gone to take the air already, sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come you with me then, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And why with you
Antiquity? I have heard you all this while,
And though you boast you have an interest in me,
We are not yet one volume, both bound up
And clasped together.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: She speaks in his element.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, I am yet loose paper; and 'twere good
To keep me so; for when I'm bound I must
Obey, be searched, examined and corrected.
Yet this I'll do, and now be serious,
If you will all obey my rule; and try
Your fortunes who shall have me.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: We agree.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Their merits bear no aequability
With mine.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: A very Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You boast your worth, and stand on confidence
In powerful advocates: but what are all
Unto my love, and (Which is more) my will?
If you will hear my proposition, hear it.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: We are agreed. Pray hear't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let's hear it then.
The gods, in love, whilom have stooped with men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That you all love me, I believe; and am
Content that every one of you do think
himself prime man in my affection:
And one of you I'll take. But yet my choice
Must wait upon Eudina's. Therefore mark
If your lord wins the Princess, and becomes
The Kings immediate heir, I will be yours;
If your lord, yours.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Therein the odds is mine,
For they are both my lords.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then if both have her, I'll be yours: not else.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: As whilom said, none of the wisest clerks,
When the sky falls we shall have store

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Of whilomes: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Var. Ter.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your mistress, lady, Princess, and my mother
Shall know your.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Away, old whilom.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your lords too I'll acquaint.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Away, old child,
Go tell it mother, do.
If you had spent, in the philosophers school
Your time no better, than in Cupid's lectures,
What a strange dunce you had been. Tell her, love shows
In you, as whilom — she knows what she knows.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your love I will forget; your scorn remember
In black revenge, and so —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Farewell December.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: He'll to his mother now. But tell me, Doris,
What means that beldame in she knows, she knows:
She's often up with't to the governess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
