sp.l: It has relation to some uncouth passage
Betwixt them, in my lady's youth I guess,

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: 'Tis some smock-secret I believe. But gentlemen,
You know how I have laid myself out to you.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That, as the Princess shall bestow herself
On either's lord; you will embrace his man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And to that you'll hold?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes
This for a creed, that heaven must make its choice and hold you
of one of them, before she take the other.
You understand me; and now cease your strife:
When th'ones lord's dead, I'll be the others wife.
So farewell gentlemen. I have stayed too long.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: She has given us both a hint now, would we take it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You did not hear me say, kill you his lord,
Nor you kill his.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: But she has laid a ground
To end a strife, that I should ne'er ha'found.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Varillus, come, our lords may be returned:
And we be shent for loitering.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I must think on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now for my combatants. Th'appointed ground
Is here; the time draws on; and the event
Foreseen in my imaginary light
Of every pass projected in their fight.
In the first passage, each shall wound the other;
Then shall they give, lend, pay, change wound for wound,
Till both of them lie fainting on the ground.
Holding between their teeth their doubtful lives:
When I, to end the question, friendly come in,
And with an equal hand dispatched 'em both.
And so into my ambush. One approaches.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: This is the place. What is't that urges me
So promptly to deed, which being acted,
Will be th'astonishment of heaven and earth?
Applauded nowhere but in hell. Fair Tempe,
Let it not be derived to after ages,
By any uncouth mark upon thy face,
Let not thy grassy locks, that shall receive
the drops of blood, wither and die, condemning
The place that bore them to continual baldness;
Let not the impress of our labouring feet
Hold it's proportion; nor that part of earth,
Whereon the slain shall measure out his length,
Reserve the stamp, and make it monumental,
By a perpetual spring of more procere
And bigger bladed grass: and, when my soul
Hath found an exit (Which my purpose is
My brother's sword shall open) let the valley
(When he's departed) sink and undermine
The bordering hills that they may cover me.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: He hath prevented me in haste: in death
I shall prevent his happily expected
Labour and toil, who for no other end
Am here arrived but to be sacrificed
For expiation of his discontent.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Let all the eyes of heaven be hooded, only
One star to guide his point unto my heart,
Which instantly shall fall, and be extinct
In my distilled blood; that so the gods
May not behold him. May some magic spell
Instruct his arm and weapon how to slay
My name and memory, that of me, there be not
Any desire; on him no imputation.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: My cure is only how my breast may swallow
His point, without revealing mine intent.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: I so't shall be: a violent assay
For provocation; and then spit myself
Upon his steel.
sp.stage: They espy one another draw, and pass at each other, instantly both spread their arms to receive the wound.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Philargus. What! so quick,

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: What's meant by this?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: That should be my demand

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Are you so changeable?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Not I Philargus.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: This was my resolution;
Will you stain
The reputation raised of your high valour.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I came to make experiment of none
But what consists in suffering.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: That's my part.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Myself
If you deny me that last friendly office.

sp.speaker: Phila.
sp.l: Brother you dally with me. Therefore I conjure you
By fair Eudina let your anger loose;
Break up this cask of blood, and give the earth
A draught unto her health.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: By the same beauty
(Than which no greater subject of an oath)
I swear to be your nuptials sacrifice,
Be you the priest. I'll suffer without noise
In my displayed bowels you shall read
An augury of bliss unto you both.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: This is hard measure, Philocles, to mock
Ere you destroy.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I'll mock no more. Adieu.
sp.stage: He offers to kill himself, Philargus closes with him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Hold, hold, and be not prodigal of that blood,
More precious than Pactolus golden streams.
sp.stage: They struggle, and both fall down, still striving to hold each others sword. Etc.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Was then your challenge but to try me only?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Yours was, it seems; but none went out from me.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Then are we both ensnared by treachery.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: This I foresaw 'twould come to. Save ye lordings.
And whither travail ye? Do you not want a guide
To help ye on your way?
sp.stage: Matho draws they start up and disarm him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: This is the villain
That summoned me.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: And me. Villain, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Unhappily guessed. I pray inquire no further.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: What monster art thou?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Unworthy on thy face to bear man's ensign.
Who has suborned thee? See 'tis Stratocles' man.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Die villain, die. And were thy master in thee,
The thirst of whose ambition sought our bloods;
His flesh with thine should here become a prey
Unto the ravens.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: O, be pitiful
And spare my life, my lords, and I'll reveal
Matters of weight and wonder; which, concealed,
Will yet cost both your lives, and make the Princess,
If she not answer my lords fierce desires,
Subject to rape and murder.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: How can she
So fall into his power.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: We shall abuse
The trust the gods have put into our hands
If we neglect to execute justice on thee.

sp.speaker: Math
sp.l: Let me but warn ye of Eudina's danger,
Whereby her virgin innocence may not suffer,
And then inflict your furies on me.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: That charms our ready hands and steel. Speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: This very hour she's to be surprised
By my lord Stratocles, here, on Tempe plains,
Where she is come to walk, slenderly guarded
To take the air. He with a strength will seize her
And hurry her hence unto his mansion house,
To yield to his desire, or death, if suddenly
Prevention be not made.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Tis worth our care.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Preserve me from his vengeance, and I'll bring you
Unto his enterprise.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: We must not trust him,
he may have laid an ambuscado for us.

sp.speaker: Philar
sp.l: See brother, stand upon our guard.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Help, help, aid me good people, help.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: What means the villain now.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: What's the complaint?

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: What is your grievance, speak?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I am a servant to lord Stratocles
Who has preserved your Country and your lives.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: We are the more beholding to him; on.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: 'Twas more his gentleness then our deserving; on.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: These two are his malignant enemies;
And finding that my lord is in these parts
Together with the Princess, fair Eudina
(Who has made him her choice) they lie in wait
To murder him, as they had me, had not
The gods sent you to rescue me.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: 'Twas more their gentleness, than your deserving, on.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I have no more to say, but that you take 'em
On your allegiance to safe custody,
And let me pass.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Un'ch, that would be more
Our gentleness than your deserving too. on, on.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Dear friends —

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Good, interrupt us not we'll hear ye in order.
On you, sir, ere you go; and come not back
For any thing unspoken you left behind.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I thank you, sir, I had like to ha'left my sword deserving,
Behind, which they disarmed me of.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: That was their gentleness more than your
(They having three swords, and you none to guard you)
They killed you not indeed, yet on again.
What further do you charge 'em with.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No more, nor you, less you detain me longer.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Now you grow bold, and saucy I must tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: Now you're a knave, a villain and a traitor,
Lest you no more behind you but a sword?
I saw a scabbard on your face of late,
A false one: seek it out.

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.l: Oh here it is.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Put it him on again. On with it, on.
Resist and we will hang thee. Now my lords,
My Princess I may say: for one of you
Must be our King. We know you though you know
Not us; you may perhaps hereafter know us
More by your gentleness than our deserving.

sp.speaker: Phil. Phil.
sp.l: O worthy country men.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: We are the heads of Tempe; and the chief
Swain heads of Thessaly (The King has known us)
And here we came to lay our heads together
For good of common wealth. Here at the verge
Of this adjoining thicket is our bower
Of consultation; and from thence (Regardful
Ever with eye and ear for common good)
We saw a beard pulled off; and heard that mouth,
(Which now is dumb) open a plot, unlike
The pitiful complaint he made to us.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But saw you not some passages before?
Of his attempt upon our lives?

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Good gods.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: No we came in but then. Those are enough
To hang the man, and turn his lord out of
Our country favour: if we find he has
That plot upon the body of the Princess
Of rape and murder. He can be no King
For us: for, sirrah, we have wives and daughters.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Stand close. See who comes here.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: So, now go back my friends. There's some reward.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Thanks to the noble bounteous Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Srat.
sp.l: Lady your tears are bootless.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Help ye gods.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your cries as unavailable. The gods
(To whom your friendly foolish lovers
Have sacrificed each other) have given you up
to me the only worthy of you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: No they are both sublimed into one star,
Yet of a double influence, that shall
Strike death into thy purposes, and give
Me light by which t'ascend with them to live
After my present death.
sp.stage: She offers to kill herself with a knife, he holds her.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your haste to death shall not prevent my lust.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She must outlive thy lust and the false traitor

sp.speaker: Rus tic
sp.l: Hold, hold, disarm, but kill him not.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: We'll keep him tame.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You have odds o'me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I am in heaven already.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Live wonder of the heavens, a star on earth
Out shining theirs.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What a short journey 'tis
For heavenly minds to reach unto the gods!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Betrayed!

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: No not betrayed. You're but well meet my lord,
But that's our gentleness more than your deserving.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Am I become the shame and scorn of peasants.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Or if you'll have't betrayed, then blame your own
Overmuch policy and want of beasts
To carry it to market. We ne'er lay
More burden on a ass, than he can bear
Here in the country: what is done at court
We know not. Here perhaps is one can tell,
Know you this bearded satire?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Coward, slave,
Thy faintness hath betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No, 'twas odds,
Such as men meet that fight against the gods.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: The fellow has some grace; he weeps: but come
Princess and princes, what is now your pleasure
We do unto these men?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: For me, I have learned
by mine own sufferings in my afflictions
To be compassionate. I wish their pardon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That mercy wounds me deeper with remorse
Then all my lost designs, and their derision
Have done with indignation.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: There is some hope these yet may prove new men.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Lord Stratocles,
Those wounds that pierce the heart with true contrition
Do bring the precious balm in 'em that cures it.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: We wish yours may be such.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: And that this shame
May guard you innocent of future blame.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: Here's sweetness upon sweetness.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Now it remains, that we advise ourselves,
Brothers of Tempe, that since these delinquents
Are fallen into our hands, that we discharge
Our country loyalty with discretion,
And not release him from our power, but by
The power above us. (That's the Kings) we'll wait
On you to court. On you for your new loves,
And you for old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I'll acquaint my father with your care,
He shall be witness of our bringing in
The ambitious politic trapped in his own gin.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bereft of all my joys and hopes at once!
Is there no comfort, nor no counsel left me?
Why stand you gazing thus with sealed lips?
Where is your counsel now, which you are wont
In trifling matters to pour out in plenty?
Now, in the peril of my life and state
I cannot get a word. Give me my daughter,
or take my kingdom too. Where is she? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: All we can say or hear is, she was taken
Out of her private walks by violent hands,
Only we guess the master of the plot
Was Stratocles, who now is missing in the court.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He asked my leave to leave the court, and had it.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: 'Twas a fit gloss for his fowl treachery.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But what ha' you said for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: We have dispatched a hundred several posts
To every coast and angle of your kingdom:
No way of finding her is left unsought.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Could we find Stratocles, she might be found.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Still upon him? Where's Philocles? where's Philargus?
They are missing too.

sp.speaker: Dis ▪
sp.l: Hell has not in't a thought
That can detract their honours.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Yet a rumor
Is spread about the court; they are gone to fight.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: 'Gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Against themselves. Nay more, that they
Have fought, and both are slain.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: You may as soon
Believe the Arctic and Antarctic poles
Can meet it opposition, amid
The firmament, and jointly in a fall
Extinguish both their lights in Neptune's bosom.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Whence springs this rumor.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Stratocles is the head
We may be confident; and his men the pipes
That have dispersed it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Still you judge Stratocles.
What purpose can he have in't.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O my sister
Has heard the news too. Weep not tender sister,
Your sons are safe.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yes they are with the gods.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And, had they ta'en Eudina with them too,
My doubts and fears were over, well as yours.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Here's one that makes a face, an ugly one,
And would weep too, had she but moisture in her.
How now! Whose mare's dead, Garrula? Take thy bottle
And turn that into tears. Or dost thou wring
thy face because that's dry? Gi' me 't, I'll fill it.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My son, o, o my son is at death's door.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: And is death so unkind to keep it shut
Against him? Out upon him churl.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My liege
And madam (It shall out) you might have saved
My son's life in your servants love, whose scorn
Will be his death, except the King divert it,
And I shall tell him what you know I know —

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O me undone.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And open such a secret
Unto his majesty —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet forbear me now.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Do you slight me in the care of my son's life?
Do you scorn my secret too, that may be worth
More than your kingdom to you?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Away old fool.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Now you shall never know't.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: For thy good will
The King would thank thee, in offering at some mirth
To cool his grief, but that it is too hot
Yet to be touched.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Indeed you do not well
To move the King, or to perplex the lady
Now in their sorrows fullness.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: What's their sorrow
To mine? My sons a dying.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Her sons are dead,
And the King's daughter lost.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: But I pray, say,
Is my lord Philocles and Philargus dead?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: 'Tis said so.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Then I say my son shall live.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: And so wilt thou while thou canst lift thy bottle
To that old mazer.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Hem! A hem! A ha!

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Do you rejoice, and show the rotten half tooth
You have left that they are dead.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: No I rejoice
That the advancement that the giglet gaped for
In one of their fine followers is lost,
In hope of which she scorned my son. But now
He shall scorn her and live.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Out envious trot

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: I'll comfort him with the news.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Away you hag,
Here comes one merry look.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Joy to the King.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Well said, speak up and home good

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Your daughter's safe returned so is your son, madam,
For which you are to thank the gods: this is
Their true relation.
sp.stage: He gives the King a paper.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Where is Stratocles?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Caught in the snares of his foul treachery.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Bravely and honestly spoken Eupathus.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And by their hands whose voices he had once
For his election.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What his country heads?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: They all turn head upon him now.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Brave heads
Observe my judgement now, my King: those heads
I will so souse in our best Greekish wines,
That they shall be such heads! O heads, heads, heads!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do approve your judgement good Disanius,
But wish you not insult o'er man's dejection.
We find that Stracocles is much penitent
And troubled at his trespass.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: A halter still him
For an ambitious hypocritical traitor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The time for my Eudina's match draws near,
And I no longer will attend on fortune,
I have decreed it passed recall, regardless
Whether against the oracle, or with it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet am I confident in your assertion
You priests of Delphos.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: He'll bestow her yet
On Stratocles, if she stand longer doubtful
In a fair choice.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Fear not my lord. That doubt
Your country heads will clear. He has lost them
For ever.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O brave heads! I will so ring
Their ears with jewels of praises and preferment
That they shall glare like direful comets at him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: One she shall choose of them: if not, I'll put
A third upon her.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: With your pardon sir,
Why are you (For I find it is so) stronger
For Philocles?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No reason urges me;
And yet I find an inclination in me
That pleads for him. I can perceive you too,
Are partial towards Philargus. Can you yield
a reason for't?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yes, sir, he is my eldest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas, but not an hour. Well, I'll remit
My power propounding, and accept
Her choice of either, made within the time.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Ay, there my hopes do anchor; else they were
Certain of shipwreck: yet the perilous waves
My vessel rides on seems so many graves.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Brother, and friend, I'm deaf to all dissuasion.
I charge you by Eudina's love, our friendship,
And (If there be) ought that you hold more sacred,
Move not to alter my fixed resolution.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: That resolution's mine; and I conjure you
By the selfsame respects, and all that are
Or may be hollowed, to let me depart.
I will remove but for some few day's journey
Whence you shall duly hear from me. But rather
I'll travail to th' antipodes, then here
Linger the vain impediment of your joys
In your Eudina.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Travel's my design.
Eudina must be yours. She is a bliss
Which heaven created for you.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Can a bliss
Be purchased with your absence? No: 'twil torture
Equally in fruition as in want.
Were it a kingdom only, we could part it
Without the quarrel of the Thebean brothers;
Or, were it heaven itself, Castor and Pollux
Should have our imitation. But Eudina
Is only indivisible.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Add to it this,
Their sentence is erroneous, that deny
Partition to the soul: for ours do witness,
Friendship can give her a division,
And make reciprocal community
Of all her faculties. But still Eudyna
Is indivisible. Why name I her,
Whom to forget must be my only task?
Brother adieu.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Tis I that must take leave.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Is it even so?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I fear we are prevented.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Nephews, why left you so the presence? I
May justly fear you were ill advised in it.
The King expects your quick return, and will not
Let pass this peremptory day, set down
For matching of his daughter; to preserve
Life, state, or kingdom. Have you a purpose,
First having begged that villain Stratocles pardon,
To give him up your interest in the Princess?
The kingdom too, to boot? will you compel
The King to give him all?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Not so good uncle.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What do you less in flying from the presence,
When that affair is now in agitation?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Uncle, you saw withal the great distraction
We left the Princess in. How when she looked
Upon Philargus, she inclined to him;
And when on me to me; when on us both
How ecstasied she fell!

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: A strong necessity
There is that one of us absent.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Therefore
You both fly off to travel several ways!
Come, let me tell you your courtesy is foolish,
And you unworthy to have such a fortune
Hang like a pregnant cloud over your heads
Ready to be dissolved in showers upon you,
While your own madness conjures up a wind
to blow't away.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Uncle, you are unjust,
I would remove to let that golden shower
Light upon Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I upon Philargus.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I could even swaddle 'em both for a brace of babies.
Your folly makes me mad: will you return
Yet to the presence, both of you?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Uncle, you know
To be both there, is neither to be there,
But to breed more perplexity in Eudyna.
Pray take Philargus.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Nephew, come, be wise:
It is a crown that courts you; and the name
Of friend, or brother ought to stand aloof,
And know a distance, where such dignity
Is tendered. Take your opportunity,
I find you coming, come.

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: I pray take Philocles.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I'll take him for the wiser man then. Nephew,
Come, and embrace your fortune, and forget not
To thank the gods your brother has no more wit.
A kingdom and a beauteous bed ▪ fellow
(There nephew, there!) Do not those bear a sound
Above friend and brother, ha?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Not in mine ears.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What frost has seized their blood, and brains, which neither
Beauty nor dignity can thaw? Go travel.
What stay you for? young gentlemen sometimes
Wait for a gale of gold to blow 'em out
O'th' harbour; Stratocles will furnish you,
And thank you more than for his forfeit life.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Stratocles can gain nothing by my absence,
While her Philargus stays.

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: No, nor by mine,
While Philocles remains.

sp.speaker: Dis
sp.l: Shall I make a motion,
Will one of you remain?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: One must and shall.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Then yield to take your lots for't. (I will make 'em)
As you respect my love; your mother's life;
The kingdoms good; Eudynas love and life,
Let it be so. Pause not upon't, but do't.
See, here's ink and paper. I am inspired,
Apollo, with thy wisdom. Love. — and friendship.
See, here's a pass for one, and a plantation
For tother. Love and friendship gentlemen.
Love shall abide at home, and friendship walk,
According to the custom of the world.
Let it be so. ▪ come study not, but draw,
I'll draw upon ye both else.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Friendship for me then.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: See here I have it brother. And yours is love.
My love be prosperous to you. My horse, my horse.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: All's ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: In the first place then bring
A parting cup, that by the grapes elizar
As Jove by Acheron, I may protest
My constancy and zeal unto my purpose.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And now's my time to act thy purpose, Doris.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Kick not your heels against the gods, Philargus,
It is most evidently their decree
That you abide and Philocles remove.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I do obey my lot. And noblest brother.
Be you as free in love, as I from envy.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But how can you forgo that equal interest
You have with me in Thessaly, and Eudina?

sp.speaker: Diss.
sp.l: Why should that trouble you? you see he does
Forego't; and is a going. Would he were gone once.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Can love allow't?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Variety of objects
Like nails abandon one a neither. So
May I, by novelties of travail, lose
The thought of love; and cheerfully return
Both hers and yours in a more just relation.
sp.stage: Enter Varillus with a bowl of wine.
sp.l: Give me the bowl. Now brother to that love
You owe the fair Eudina, unto which
I give th'addition of mine own, and all
the Joves that ere I wished myself and her,
And to that friendship, which nor time, nor absence
Shall ever end or alter.
sp.stage: He drinks and gives Varillus the bowl.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Now the service that may redeem my faults
Is to be done.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Give it me full, Varillus.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'll give you more than you expect by this.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: You have the victory in friendship, brother,
Who, by your resolute absence will enforce
And drive me to a happiness; wherein
I must not cease, in all the strength of prayers
Of sacrifice, and vows; in all my goods
Of fortune, mind and body to be yours:
Which that you may return to repossess
With the more speed, this health to auspicate
And expedite your travails.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: They are done
Already if my pothecaries skill fail not.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: With this embrace my brother, and my last
Of present ceremony, I now wish you
In th'arms of your Eudina —
And may my better part of soul, which now
I leave in trust with you, by you be breathed
Into her breast; that she may lively find
She has my love in yours; and that in you
She has us both.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: So, so, enough. Ha' ye done yet?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: How is it with you brother?

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: As it is
With souls that leave the world in peace.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: For shame
Leave womanish ceremony. Will you part
Before it be too late?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Too soon I fear.
Philargus! Brother! Friend! Ye gods, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What is he dead? I see then how it comes.
You or your man, or both ha' poisoned him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: No, 'twas myself.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Thou wilt not go out o'th' world
With a lie i'thy mouth? Speak yet again,

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: He has said well for me already,

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Gone, passed recovery, but he shall not pass
Without my company.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Wilt thou die mad too?
sp.stage: He offers to kill himself. Dis. snatcheth his sword away.
sp.l: Come, sir, let go your whiblin. He has yet
Some breath. Run for physicians — no, sir, stay.
I will not quit you so. I can read guilty lines
Palpably on this villain's visnomy.
Is there no more i'th' house? some help here! ho!
Nephew forbear. As you will have me think
sp.stage: Philocles offers again to kill himself.
sp.l: You guiltless of your brother's blood, forbear.
How am I tortured! Ho! Philargus; rub him,
Rub him, he may live yet.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: O that the world
Might be so happy!

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: So, well said: a box
Or two in kindness will not do amiss.
Stir not you sirrah. O, sir, you lay hold
On that same traitor.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'll not stir my lord.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I'll hold you to your word, sir, run, sir, you
And fetch physicians.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O my lord, fallen dead!

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Stay but to look upon him, and I'll swear
Thou art his murderer. Fetch the King's physicians,
If not to cure him; yet to rip the cause
Out of his sudden death. I guess they'll find
Your handiwork in's maw.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You heard him say
It was himself that did it. I am cleared.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My lord, the King, impatient of your stay,
Has sent it.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What has he sent. Has he sent means
To call this man from death, or that from falling
After him into th'grave?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: O heavy spectacle!

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: But, come I will not cry though. Pray assist me,
In with this body, charity commands
when grieved necessity entreats your hands.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My rustici amici, your council and
Your virtue have restored me. And 'tis true
As Wholom said the good Antisthenes'
Virtue is armour 'gainst the very fates.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: We told you for your good, good Mr. Geron,
Fond love became you not.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: It sat upon your coat like burrs or briars
Stuck in the hindlocks of our fleecy sheep;
Who shake their heads; figgle, and writhe their tails,
And bleat for woe; sprinkle the ground behind 'em
Sometimes I wiss: 'twould make one laugh and pity 'em
And all at once, but all remediless.
Till we with helping wit and hands release 'em

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: A wise man then in love is like a sheep
Ith' briars. As whilom said

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.l: But (By the way)
What was that whilom, sir, you speak much of him,
But what was he prey.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: An ancient Britain, whom I have affected
As idly as my love. But I'll forget it
And use that word no more. The clowns have found me.

sp.speaker: 4. Rus tic
sp.l: But will you now proceed upon your plot
For th'honour of Tempe plains, and Tempe swains.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You can all dance.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: After our country guise.

sp.speaker: 3. Rus tic
sp.l: Like so many light horses.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: So can our wives
Who have followed us up to court we thank 'em
pray Juno we get them honestly home again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: There is no doubt. However fear you nothing
As why — 'tis hard to leave off an old custom.

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: The why was out, but loom stuck in your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis well it did so. You can dance you say.
A dance I have projected for the Princess
Whoever marries her it shall serve. As why —

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Again 'twas e'en a coming.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You are as quick as why —

sp.speaker: 2. Rus tic
sp.l: And there again.

sp.speaker: 1. Rus tic
sp.l: Nay we are heads, I tell you master Geron,
And should have wit; and show't we can i' th'country,
In the head vein, though hear at court, like courtiers
We'll show it in our heels. Pray therefore on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: On, let us then to practise. King and court
Shall see, to crown their joys, some country sport.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No answer, no return? Must I entreat,
Yet have my undeserved favours slighted?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet, sir, your kingly patience.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stupid folly
'Twere longer to attend. My vow is past
And registered in heaven; the minute is
At hand, that calls down thunder on me, which
No tear, or prayers can mollify or aver't,
If I upon so long deliberation
Shall falsify. So, call in Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O my dread father. Yet one hours patience
Till Eupathus or Disanius return.
One short, short hour: I may not live so long.
His wife you named; though you may force me take him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'll leave that to the gods.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: They will forgive. Give them your imitation
In mercy, as in power on earth. I know Disanius
Went not in vain to call 'em to your presence.
And him that he brings first into this room
Oh Philocles or Philargus I will take,
Though he precede the other but one foot,
I have it by inspiration from the gods.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You are full of dreams.

sp.speaker: Thym.
sp.l: This cannot, sir, be long
In trial. King yet I am not bound to wait
On those ingrateful men. O Stratocles,
You have from your late errors, which your then
Headstrong ambition hurried and cast you in
With that humility purged yourself, that I
Conceive you now a temperate man; and am
Instructed by the clemency of the gods
To cherish and reward your virtue. Therefore
From their divine appointment, as my hands —

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: (Oh mighty, sir —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dare not to disobey me)
Receive Eudina.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Royal King and master,
Mistake not so the pleasure of the gods.
My forfeit life you have forgiven me:
Your kingly power and grace might do it. You
Have given it freely: but I took't with caution,
By future service to make good your gift:
But for my forfeit love to fair Eudina,
And my lost honour to the twin-born brothers,
There can be no redemption, if I add
By acceptation of your bounteous offer
A second trespass, greater than the former.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Do you refuse her then.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: In hope she'll plead
My pardon to your grace.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: The gods have wrought
Effectually for me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Strangely, unexpected
Are you become a suppliant Placilla?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: In the behalf, sir, of your loyal subjects,
The swains of Tempe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I expected, rather,
News from your unkind brothers. See Justinius,
The commons, rather than I shall bestow
My daughter upon Stratocles, do beseech me
To take a further time.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: You're happy, sir,
In his refusal and in their request.
They are fair predictions of ensuing joys
To you, your daughter, and the kingdom, if
I may be worthy to divine so much.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Howe'er thy divination proves, thy wish
Is worth our thanks. And we may have
Glad tidings presently. Now Eupathus
Where is Disanius, Philocles, and Philargus?
Why come they not?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: They are all at hand my liege.
This paper may excuse their stay.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O do
They plead excuse then?

sp.speaker: Thym.
sp.l: I am full of fears.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: And I of sudden joy.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Pray all be well.
The King has struck his breast, and seems perplexed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Justinius, Stratocles, read here this paper.
Go Eupathus, and let them enter. Stay.
Yet go, bring them in their prescribed manner.
I'll send the woman off, whose sudden grief
May be a bar to our proceedings. Madam —

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I fear that Garrula has detected me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I must entreat a while your absence, lady.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: May I presume to ask your reason, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My will has been above your question. Pray,
Let me request you go.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I know obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And go Placilla, send old Garrula to me.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now 'tis most evident. O mighty, sir,
Conceive not worse of me then Garrula.
Let us appear together.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may be pleased to hear me first.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Pray pull not
More weight upon your breast than you can bear,
by your impertinent stay. Go I command you.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I must obey. However 'tis too late
To change the resolution of my fate.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I have not known her thus. I fear distraction
Foreruns the voice of grief, as to prevent it.
Heaven knows I called for Garrula, but to send her
With best directions to prepare and arm
Her tender soul against the sting of sorrow
Before it should approach her. But Eudina
You must be valiant; and not let the sight
Of death in others shake your confidence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: How means your majesty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Suppose that both
Your fatal lovers, Philocles and Philargus
Slept in the caves of death.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I should not live then;

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Suppose his destiny had cut off one,
And, in him, all the impediments, that crossed
You in th' enjoying of the other, say
Which could you wish survivor? But you have
Declared your constant purpose to possess
The first Disanius brings into this presence.
Come; one is dead. There is a strict necessity
You know it. Now collect your reason: for 'tis not
Your passion for the dead; nor your dislike
Of Stratocles; no though my subjects yield you
A longer time, shall make me tempt the gods
sp.stage: Recorders. Ent. Disanius before a hearse. Philocles after. Varillus manacled and led by Tersulus. Euputhus supports Philocles, as ready to sink with grief.
sp.l: By breaking of my vow. Be steadfast then,
As you respect a father; and take courage.
See Philocles lives.

sp.speaker: Eud
sp.l: Philargus then
Is brought in dead before him by Disanius;
And unto him the first to be brought in
My faith was vowed; and he is now my choice.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What being dead? Could you affect 'em so
Equally, both alive, that you forbore
To choose, because you could not have 'em both;
and now seek only him cannot be had?
sp.stage: The hearse set down. Eudinae kneels to it. Philo. kneels
sp.l: What love, what madness call you this? good gods,
Throw not your wrath upon me in destruction on the other

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Nor let your passion master you great, sir, side,
As sudden grief does her. But give a little
Scope to her sorrow. She will soon return
And meet her reason in obedience
To your desires.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thank thee good Justinius.
sp.stage: During which Disanius etc. discourse with the King. Disanius seems to acquaint the King with the manner of Philargus' death, pointing at Varillus. The King seems much troubled; but at the end of the song, (As by the King's appointment Disanius raiseth Philocles, and Justinius raiseth Eudina, and bring them to the King while Eupathus with the attendants go forth with the hearse, the recorders playing. which done,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your virgin tears and vows o'er your lost love
I did attend with pardon, my Eudina,
In hope you are now compliant to my will.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Grieve not your father madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I ha'done;
And as the gods direct him to command me,
I must and will obey.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: So that's well said.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The gods have pleased Eudina to determine
Your doubtful choice, reserving Philocles
Unto your love without competitor:
Therefore it now remains that he be taken
Into your liking; whom I have decreed
My successor.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: His merits are above
Me and this land; in which what interest
My birth hath given me I resign to him.
Only let me beseech a further respite.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For what? the celebration? I consent;
But for the contract, this immediate hour
Shall see it knit beyond all dissolution.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I that I thirst to see.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give me your hands.
Yours Philocles.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Why give you not your hand,
Dare you not trust the King with't? should he now
Show a jade's trick and fly back.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I beseech
Under your highness' pardon, yet, a respite.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: More respites yet? Was ever hopeful match
Driven so round about?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why this delay?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: My brother's blood cries in me for your justice
Which must be executed on his murderer
Before I safely can, or dare possess
His interest in the faith of fair Eudina.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O, is that all? that may be soon dispatched.
Come forwards poisoner. Good your majesty,
For expedition, make me his judge,
And hangman too (I care not) rather than
Suffer this match hang o'the tenters thus.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Has he confessed the fact?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Yes, yes to me.
I beat it out of him. Quickly good King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your patience good Disanius' sirrah speak.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: It was my act. But may your mercy look
Upon my love in it unto my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your lord shall be your judge then.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I adjudge him
To sharp but lingering tortures (For his death
Alone can yield no satisfaction)
Tortures that may draw in, by his confession,
As accessaries with him, all the homicides
That are i'th' kingdom.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: A hard matter that.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Nor can I think his only brain and hands
Composed the poison.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Hang him, he's a barber,
And uses aqua fortis, oil of vitriol,
Mercury, and such like, to cleanse his razors.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: 'Tis good that you Varillus clear your conscience
And, if you had confederates in the fact,
Give up their names.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Varillus, I suspect
Doris joined hand with you in my lord's death.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It shall out my lord;
The handmaid Doris put him on't; I know't
By what she said to us both we being her lovers.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: The tailor proves an honest man: because
He cannot have the wench himself, he'll hang her.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Of her I had the poison, 'tis confessed.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O that whore. King. Find her and drag her hither.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Where's my Philargus? Give me yet his body,
That with a mother's tears I may embalm it.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: You have heard the woeful news then; but my sister
Could grief recall Philargus, we would weep
A second deluge for his reparation;
Renew his breath by sighing, and awake him,
With groans out of his sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Already
Have you interred him then? you made strange haste.
Was it your subtlety to send me hence,
Fearing my cries might have revived him, King?
And so again delayed your daughter's marriage?
I have enough to cross it yet Philargus

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Distraction sure.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My fear foresaw't.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You are deceived, for from my depth of sorrow,
Through this thick film of tears, I can perceive
You are about to join the hands and faiths
Of Philocles and Eudina,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is not that
Enough to dry your tears, and show, you that
The gods were rather merciful in leaving
This son, then rigorous in taking tother?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Or would you now, cause you have lost Philargus,
Kill Philocles too by crossing of this contract?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: It is the pleasure of the gods I cross it.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Of devils it is. What can she mean? Go sleep.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: King by your leave.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: What says old suckbottle now?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Nay I am here before you Garrula,
And now will tell the long hid secret for you.
And if I err in it, disprove me.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Tell't then.
My faltring tongue will fail me. I can hear though.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This contract must not be.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You then must yield
More reason than I find you have.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yourself
Can never make it. You will sooner join
The wolf and lamb. Falcon and dove together.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No trifling I command you Thymele.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: If you be serious, mother, hold us not
In this suspense.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Let not the royal blood
Of Thessaly be stained with an incestuous match.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: She says right. They are both your lawful children
By your own virtuous Queen now in — Elysium.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What dreams are these of your distempered heads,

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This is no dream or fable. But unfeigned
As truth itself: which with your gracious leave
I shall demonstrate, humbly craving pardon
For my so long concealment, as I'll yield
Due reason for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Freely speak, you have it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may remember in your civil wars,
(Those cruel wars, as I may justly style 'em)
In which my husband fell —

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: O my brave brother!

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: When open rebels and domestic traitors
Pursued your crown and life; your gracious Queen
To have been brought to bed; and was believed
To have miscarried by an abortive birth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: True: in her flight she was constrained to take
A neighbouring cottage; and use the help
Of the swains wife.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: That swain-ess was myself,
Though my deserts have glorified me since:
And by my help (And somewhat of the gods)
she then made you the father of that prince.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Take up thy bottle — sister, speak you on.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Th'affrighted Queen (Yet wise in that extremity)
Suspecting that the innocence of her babe
Born to a kingdom, could not be secured
In those combustions from apparent danger,
Sent him to me in private, then in travel
Of my Philargus — charging me to fain
A second labour, with the midwife's aid,
For Philocles: I did, and was reputed
Mother of both.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I cannot think our Queen
Would keep us ignorant of so good a fortune.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I moved her oft to tell you. But she answered,
All is not sound, there's danger, yet; and when
After Eudyna's birth she felt herself
At point of death, she strictly did enjoin
Me and this woman, only conscious with her,
By oath of which she had prepared this copy
In her own hand, to keep it silent, till
Philocles should be able to secure
Himself from treachery; or that your term
Of life expiring, or some accident
Of no less consequence required detection.
For further proof —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My joy forbids more questioning
Give me my flesh and blood into my bosom.
Thrice happy fathers if your children were
Born to you thus of perfect age. But where
Is now a match for my Eudina. I
Have here a successor.
sp.stage: A shout within and crying Philargus, Philargus. Etc.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! Voices i'th air that cry Philargus?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Voices that do tell me, I must follow him
Up to the heavens, and there be married to him.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: Here's the she-devil now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You need not pull me
For that man's love, I laid thy lord to sleep:
Had I loved thee best, than his lord had slept.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: How does he sleep? speak impudent baggage, how?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How? With a powder, sir, which my own father
A skilful apothecary prepared; who, if
Philargus die, shall hang with us for company.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Your father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, but now the perils past.
See, if he sleep, 'tis walking.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Ha! Philargus.
Or but the shade; the spirit of my friend.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Be not amazed, as at an apparition.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Doth my son live? O then I have enough.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Come hither. come hither you three. I will discharge
The scene of you ▪ thy love unto thy lord
(Though somewhat unadvisedly employed)
Deserves reward; I'll see it given thee,
Thy lord and King shall thank thee: take thy wench,
She has love in her wit, and wit in her anger.
I like the luck of things; that ill intents
Should bring forth good events. Thy faithfulness
To thy lord too was happy. Go, I ▪ le see you
All royally rewarded. How now Geron?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My lord I see here's joy towards, as why —

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: 'Slife, stand not whiloming now man: but be brief.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Cry mercy. I had left it. But my lord
To celebrate the flowing joys in court,
I and my country heads have framed a masque,
Rather an antic dance, rather a country toy,
Rather a rustic round; rather a —

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Hoy day!
Thy rather's worse than thy whilom. Dost know
What time o'day 'tis.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis a rural thing
to be presented at the Princess wedding
And, if you think it meet, I will induce
The practice of it presently. As why —

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Go fetch the heads and heels, I'll stay the King,
To see and laugh at 'em. That's grace enough.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Philargus you have much to know; the which
We will Eudina tell you, now she's yours.
Receive her and our blessing.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Were I dead
(As I was thought to be) your name pronounced
Over my grave, beyond all necromancy,
Would call fresh blood into my veins again;
Strengthen my nerves, to break the iron gates
Of death; and force my joyful spirit from
Th' Elysian paradise to live with you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You shall not be a looser Thymele:
Philocles shall be yours, and in exchange
Placilla mine.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: To me my beauteous spouse
Thou art as Juno to her Jupiter,
Sister and wife.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your highness may be pleased
Now at so happy leisure to perpend
The oracle; which truly hath effected
Each word of the prediction.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Who can repeat the answer, I ha'lost it.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: I have it.
Contend not for the jewel, which
Ere long shall both of you enrich.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Eudina does so: me in a dear sister.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Me in a peerless wife.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Pursue your fortune: for 'tis she
Shall make ye what you seem to be.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She has done that too: for now indeed we're brothers

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Apollo thou hast filled us all with joy,
but has our joy already filled our court
With music?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Will your majesty yet sit
And see the practice of a presentation,
Against the marriages by your swains of Tempe
With thanks; and give it all the grace we may?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: From Tempe plains, the Tempe swains
sp.stage: Enter Geron and the swains and nymphs for the dance.
sp.l: With mirth and melody,
With dance and song do hither throng
To greet your majesty.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: O there, look there, madam my son, and all
My old Temperian neighbours.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We cannot hope in all our scope,
To gain much praise for skill,
But it shall be enough, if ye
Accept of our good will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My thanks to all.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Heaven bless your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks to Apollo. Let his temple be
The place of our solemnity. His altars
Let them be laden with Arabian spices;
Let his priests lead, in a devout procession,
The horned sacrifice, mantled with garlands
And we (Our temples crowned with laurel) follow
With music, sounding Hymen and Apollo.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: 'Tis not the poet's art, nor all that we
By life of action can present unt'ye
Can justly make us to presume a play
Is good till you approv't: which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, since our gains
Come by your favour more than all our pains.
Thus to submit us unto your commands
And humbly ask that favour at your hands.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
